questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the deep inguinal ring, which is formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: A 32 year old female who is a  known case of Crohn's disease underwent ileal resection for the presence of stricture. She became a strict vegan post surgery and several months later presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands. Which is the most likely reason for her symptom?
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

In addition to this, a strict vegan diet also leads to vitamin B12 deficiency as meat and dairy products are avoided which are rich sources of vitamin B12.

B12 deficiency :

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin(Vit B12) deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anaemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (subacute combined degeneration). 
  • Psychiatric disturbances

 

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1- Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3- Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4- Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Finding Bleeding disorders Coagulation disorders
Cause Quantitative/Qualitative platelet abnormality Deficiency of clotting factors
Sex More common in females (commonly autoimmune) More common in males (commonly X-linked)
Family history Rare (except in VWD) Common
Petechiae Characteristic  Rare
Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)
Deep dissecting hematomas Rare Characteristic (most common-iliopsoas)
Laboratory tests Bleeding time is prolonged PT and/or PTT are prolonged
Most common Inherited: VWD

Inherited: Hemophilia A

Acquired: Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver disease

VWD: von Willebrand disease

PT: Prothrombin time

PTT: Partial thromboplastin time

Related Pearl: Summary of Laboratory findings in Hemostatic Disorders

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of Leptospirosis.

A history of fever with liver(icterus) and kidney(hematuria) involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

Other Options

Option A: Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. The clinical presentation of typhoid fever includes a stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation, which is different from the clinical scenario described.

Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections like typhus fever, which is caused by Rickettsia species. The clinical manifestations of typhus fever include fever, rash, and headache, which are not consistent with the clinical scenario described.

Option D: Paul-Bunnell test, also known as the Monospot test, is used for the detection of heterophile antibodies in infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). The clinical features of infectious mononucleosis include fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, which are not consistent with the present case.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male with diabetes mellitus presented to the clinic. Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs causes glycosuria?
questions.solution:
Empagliflozin acts by inhibiting sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) transporter, which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a decrease in blood glucose level. It is effective orally.

Additionally, the increased urinary glucose excretion leads to osmotic diuresis, resulting in the removal of excess fluid from the body. Common side effects of empagliflozin include genital mycotic infections, and volume depletion-related adverse events such as hypotension and dizziness.

Additionally, the notable side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine and also increases the risk of fractures.

Other SGLT2 inhibitors include canagliflozin and ertugliflozin.

Other options:

(a) Glipizide: Glipizide belongs to the sulfonylurea class of antidiabetic drugs. It works by stimulating insulin release from the pancreas, thereby lowering blood sugar levels. However, glipizide does not directly affect the excretion of glucose in the urine or fluid removal from the body. Common side effects of glipizide include hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), weight gain, and gastrointestinal disturbances.

(c) Exenatide: Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist. It works by stimulating insulin secretion, inhibiting glucagon release, and slowing gastric emptying, leading to improved glycemic control. Exenatide does not directly affect glucose excretion in the urine or fluid removal from the body. Common side effects of exenatide include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and injection site reactions.

(d) Acarbose: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays the digestion and absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines. It does not directly affect glucose excretion in the urine or fluid removal from the body. Common side effects of acarbose include gastrointestinal disturbances such as flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort.

Conclusion: The correct answer is (b) Empagliflozin. It promotes the excretion of glucose in the urine (glycosuria) and facilitates fluid removal from the body through osmotic diuresis. This is achieved by inhibiting the SGLT2 transporter in the kidneys.

questions.text: The image shown below represents which type of mechanical asphyxia?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the image is Burking. 

Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Other options:

Option A: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

Option D: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the centre of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used.

questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child had biphasic stridor. The lesion in which of the following level will produce this type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of glottis, subglottis (B), and cervical trachea will cause Biphasic stridor.

Stridor is a noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely diagnosis in this patient presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia.

Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

Ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency include loss of sensitivity to green light (earliest to appear), nyctalopia (night blindness), and xerophthalmia.

Xerophthalmia includes conjunctival xerosis (dryness) with Bitot’s spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium appearing on the sclera), corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea) that leads to corneal scarring and ultimately, blindness.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about systematic reviews?
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is not always performed in systematic reviews. 

Steps of a Systematic Review:

  • A systematic review is the process of locating and synthesizing the research on a particular question using organized, transparent, and replicable procedures.
  • It ranks high in the hierarchy of evidence in medicine.
  • The research question formulated is always focussed.
  • The literature on studies is always found and appraised after criteria of eligibility are established.
  • Meta-analysis is usually done in a systematic review but not always.

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife conducting a vaccination camp received 2 vaccine vials. One is a pentavalent vaccine and the other is an MR vaccine, which she opened on the day of the camp. She intends to reuse these vials by storing them in proper condition, at her next vaccination camp to be conducted in 2 weeks. What would you advise her regarding the re-utilization of these vials?

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.solution:
She can use the pentavalent vaccine and discard the MR vaccine.  According to the open vial policy, the pentavalent vaccine can be reused, whereas MR can not be reused. 

Open vial policy allows for the reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV and liquid pentavalent vaccine.

It is not applicable for BCG, measles, rotavirus vaccines and JE vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be use in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water.

Ensure all opened vials have recorded date and time of opening.

At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable.

All open vials of BCG, measles and JE must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete.

All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register.

Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a crush injury on his hand. He says that he received his last dose of TT vaccination at the age of 23. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: Wound care with single dose tetanus toxoid
Wound care with full course of TT vaccine
Wound care with tetanus Ig and TT vaccine

questions.solution:
Wound care with a single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the patient is category B, with the last dose received more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization
Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents with flu-like symptoms and a palmoplantar rash as seen below. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of maculopapular rash with flu-like symptoms and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy points to secondary syphilis.

  • Secondary syphilis occurs within 6 weeks to 8 weeks of onset of primary chancre.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Onset of systemic manifestations includes symptoms such as malaise, headache, loss of appetite, sore throat
    • Generalized symmetric, asymptomatic maculopapular rash on the palms and soles of the feet
    • Generalized adenopathy in 50% cases
    • Condyloma lata are the classic findings; these are highly contagious exophytic broad excrescences that ulcer­ate. These are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area and upper thighs.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text: The ECG wave as shown in the image below is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
The above ECG wave characteristically depicts Digoxin effect.

Digoxin effect refers to the presence on the ECG of:

  • Downsloping ST depression with a characteristic “Salvador Dali sagging” or “Hockey Stick” appearance.
  • Flattened, inverted, or biphasic T waves.
  • Shortened QT interval.

Additional ECG Features:

  • Mild PR interval prolongation of up to 240ms (due to increased vagal tone).
  • Prominent U waves.
  • Peaking of the terminal portion of the T waves.
  • J point depression (usually in leads with tall R waves).

QRS complex / ST segment changes:

  • The morphology of the QRS complex / ST segment is variously described as either “slurred”, “sagging” or “scooped” and resembling either a “reverse tick”, “hockey stick” or “Salvador Dali’s moustache”.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented with chest pain that was unrelated to physical exertion. ECG showed ST-segment elevation. Intracoronary acetylcholine provocation testing revealed a transient spasm of the right coronary artery. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario in which rest pain is associated with ST-segment elevation and transient coronary vasospasm is suggestive of Prinzmetal's angina. The drug of choice is a calcium channel blocker.

Prinzmetal variant angina (PVA) is a clinical syndrome in which chest pain occurs without the usual precipitating factors. It usually results from coronary vasoconstriction (vasospasm) and tends to involve the right coronary artery.

It is a supply ischemia and usually causes transmural ischemia (subendocardial in classic angina pectoris).

It often affects women under 50 years of age. It characteristically occurs in the early morning, awakening patients from sleep, and may be associated with arrhythmias or conduction defects.

The clinical diagnosis of PVA is made by the detection of transient ST-segment elevation with rest pain. Coronary angiography demonstrates transient coronary spasm which is the diagnostic hallmark of PVA.

Nitrates and calcium channel blockers both can be used in alleviating symptoms in Prinzmetal's angina. However due to the development of nitrate tolerance in some individuals, they are less preferred and calcium channel blockers such as verapamil, diltiazem are used as first-line agents.

questions.text: Following feature (Image A) is characteristic of a certain disease. On investigation, the lady was found to have the following immunofluorescence pattern (Image B). Positivity of which of the given antibody would predict a higher risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A is a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma. Image B shows the nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and it represents antibodies to RNA). The pattern is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. Anti-scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at higher risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, scleroderma patients experience puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and Digital ulceration
  • Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma, have dysphagia, and GERD at the level of esophagus
  • Mask like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing and beak‐like nose.The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients .
  • Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti RNA polymerase III are seen in Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic sclerosis  which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstial lung disease.

Other options:

  • Anti centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
  • Anti U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.
  • Anti U3-RNP (Antifibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room following a motorcycle collision. On examination, the patient is drowsy and has decreased blood pressure due to bleeding from multiple injuries. 1 unit of packed RBCs has been obtained from the blood bank. What is the correct procedure for blood transfusion?

choices.text: The blood should be brought to room temperature before the transfusion
Transfusion should be started within one hour of removal from the refrigerator
Transfusion of PRBC should be completed within 4 hours
The rate of transfusion of PRBC is 50mL per hour

questions.solution:
The transfusion of packed RBCs (PRBC) should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours after the removal from the blood fridge. 

There is an increased risk of bacterial proliferation and loss of the function of blood components after they are removed from the storage temperatures. Hence, the transfusion should be started within 30 minutes of receiving the components from the blood bank. The packed RBCs should be infused at a rate of 100-150mL/hour. Warming of blood is not needed when the transfusion is at normal rates. The transfusion should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours.

Duration times for transfusion
Blood products  Start transfusion  Complete transfusion
Whole blood / PRBC Within 30 minutes of removing from refrigerator

≤ 4 hours 

Discard unit if this period is exceeded
Platelet concentrate  Immediately Within 30 minutes
Fresh frozen plasma As soon as possible Within 30 minutes
Cryoprecipitate As soon as possible Within 30 minutes

questions.text: Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. In a free flap the blood supply is isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using micosurgery at the new site. Other eg: DIEP (Deep inferior epigastric perforators) flap, free fibular flap

  • A random flap include three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters.Eg:V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg or rhomboid flap.
  • Axial flap is much longer and is based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus dorsi flap,TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap
  • Islanded flap are those in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Note:

Flap defines the tongue of tissue; pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

Skin-bearing flaps are classified according to three basic characteristics—

  • Composition: refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

Basic life support involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat.

Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

Other options: 

Option B: Jaw thrust- Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

 

Option D: Manual inline stabilization is a maneuver that limits external head and neck movement in patients with cervical spine injuries. Fingers and palms of both hands are used to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to ensure successful airway intervention.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: A patient after a motor vehicle accident develops breathing difficulty. On examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side, and the trachea is shifted to the left. Heart sounds are normal. There is a dull note on percussion. The chest X-ray is shown below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, dull note on percussion, and the chest X-ray showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification is suggestive of massive hemothorax. The next step of management that can be done for this patient is intercostal drainage tube(ICD) placement.

Massive hemothorax occurs when more than 1500 mL of blood, equivalent to one-third or more of the patient's blood volume, rapidly accumulates in the chest cavity. This condition is typically caused by a penetrating injury that damages major blood vessels, although it can also be the result of blunt trauma.

In patients with massive hemothorax, the neck veins may appear flat due to severe hypovolemia, or they may be distended if there is a concurrent tension pneumothorax. If a patient is in shock and exhibits an absence of breath sounds or dullness upon percussion on one side of the chest, it suggests the presence of a massive hemothorax.

The initial management of massive hemothorax involves simultaneous resuscitation to restore blood volume and decompression of the chest cavity. This is achieved by establishing large-diameter intravenous lines, administering crystalloid fluids, and initiating transfusion of blood at the earliest opportunity. A single chest tube with a diameter of 28-32 French is inserted, typically at the fifth intercostal space, just anterior to the midaxillary line. Volume restoration is rapidly continued while the chest cavity is decompressed.

The immediate return of 1500 mL or greater volume of blood typically signifies the urgent requirement for thoracotomy. Patients who initially show an output of less than 1500 mL of fluid but continue to bleed may also necessitate thoracotomy.

Needle thoracostomy and open thoracostomy are done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, and hyper-resonant note on percussion. 

Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, normal breath sounds, and muffled heart sounds. There is no mediastinal shift here.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with a history of vaginal discharge without itching. On examination, the discharge was milky, foul-smelling, nonviscous, and adherent to the vaginal wall. She is not active sexually. On further testing, it was found that the discharge has very few lactobacilli and there was a presence of clue cells. What is the causative organism for the above condition _______
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is Bacterial Vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is termed vaginosis rather than vaginitis because it is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora rather than due to any specific infection.

It is not sexually transmitted and has a variable incubation period. About 50% of women are asymptomatic carriers of infection.

The presence of clue cells is one of the 4 criteria described in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

On microscopy, there is no abundance of polymorphs in a case of bacterial vaginosis as it is just an alteration of flora and not an inflammation.

  • The diagnosis is based on wet smear and culture.
  • The smear reveals clean background with few inflammatory cells and other organ­isms, but scanty lactobacilli. Many epithelial cells present a granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, the so-called clue cells. Gram stain is 90% sensitive.

questions.text: A primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted for management of preterm labour. Which of the following tocolytics would be preferred for this?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is the preferred tocolytic as it has minimum maternal side effects.

According to ACOG guidelines, the use of tocolytics in preterm labour does not prolong gestation but may delay delivery upto 48 hours. Hence, short-term therapy with tocolytics is given for 1-3 days to delay labour for the action of corticosteroid therapy or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). 

Tocolytics used in preterm labour and their side effects:

Tocolytics Maternal side effects Fetal/ neonatal side effects

Beta-adrenergic agonists:

  • Ritodrine
  • Terbutaline
  • Isoxsuprine

Headache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary edema, cardiac failure, ARDS

Fetal heart failure, intrauterine death

Neonatal hypoglycemia, intraventricular haemorrhage

Calcium channel blockers:

  • Nifedipine
  • Nicardipine
  • Verapamil
 Hypotension, headache, flushing, nausea -

Oxytocin antagonists:

  • Atosiban

(not approved for use in India)

 Nausea, vomiting, chest pain -
Magnesium sulphate Flushing, perspiration, headache, muscle weakness, respiratory paralysis Neonatal cardiac arrest, lethargy, hypotonia, respiratory depression

COX inhibitors:

  • Indomethacin
  • Sulindac
 Heartburn, asthma, GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, renal injury, platelet dysfunction, oligohydramnios Constriction of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension, intrauterine growth restriction

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks of gestation. Twenty minutes later, the mother developed severe shortness of breath and appeared cyanotic. Her ECG and chest X-ray showed no abnormalities. Despite resuscitation, she died after a few hours. Her lab reports revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Platelets Low
Fibrinogen Low
Thrombin time Increased
Prothrombin time Increased
Partial thromboplastin time Increased
Fibrin degradation products Increased
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is amniotic fluid embolism. The given lab evaluation points to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 

Amniotic fluid embolism presents with a classic triad of hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC. Usually, it presents during the late stages of labour or immediate postpartum (peripartum period). Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features. Other causes for a similar presentation such as myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and anaphylactic shock needs to be ruled out. 

According to the American Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine, the diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labour or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever (≥38°C)

The currently accepted mechanism is the entry of fetal material into the maternal circulation which leads to the activation of proinflammatory mediator systems. This results in pulmonary vasoconstriction and hypertension. The tissue factor present in fetal material also activates factor VII resulting in DIC.

Risk factors include rapid labour, meconium-stained liquor, cesarean delivery, placenta previa, eclampsia, placental abruption, polyhydramnios, uterine tears, post-term pregnancy, and advanced maternal age.

The condition can be fatal and management includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation and advanced cardiac life support.

Autopsy findings as shown in the image below, include the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

 

Other options:

Option A: Preeclampsia is characterized by the development of hypertension to the extent of 140/90 mm Hg or more with proteinuria, after the 20th week of gestation, in a previously normotensive and non-proteinuric woman. Pre-eclampsia causes endothelial injury which in turn leads to DIC.

Option B: Tension pneumothorax can be a possible diagnosis with the patient's clinical symptoms. But a normal chest X-ray would make this diagnosis unlikely. 

Option C: Bacterial sepsis leads to endothelial injury and release of phospholipids, which in turn leads to DIC. The tissue factor that is released in response to cytokines (IL-1), tumor necrosis factor, and endotoxin. The tissue factor activates the extrinsic pathway leading to coagulopathy. Given the patient's history, an amniotic fluid embolism is more likely.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

CP is a static encephalopathy and a disorder of posture and movement often associated with:

  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • Dystonic CP is associated with hypotonia
  • Extrapyramidal CP is associated with ataxia
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

Scissoring gait is a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy as shown in the GIF below-

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to your clinic with complaints of stiffness of the joints in their fingers for the past 6 years that has progressively worsened over time. On examination, the following deformity is noted. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Swan neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by a symmetric polyarthritis and is the most common form of chronic inflammatory arthritis. A variation in the the HLA-DRB1 gene is known to cause RA. Cigarette smoking is known to increase the risk five to six fold.

Histopathological features include synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation with inflammatory infiltrates and rheumatoid nodules. These are necrotizing granulomas surrounded by fibrinoid necrosis. 

RA is a systemic disease, which potentially leads to a variety of extraarticular manifestations, including fatigue, subcutaneous nodules, interstitial lung disease and pulmonary nodules, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities, which must be managed accordingly. 

Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that relieves with activity. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger.

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and C reactive protein (CRP). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis. Progression of joint damage is assessed by plain X-ray.

Management comprises of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief, along with disease modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARD). Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice. Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) is given as an adjuvant in combination with other DMARDs. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, anakinra and rituximab are known to reduce the signs and symptoms of RA, slow radiographic progression of joint damage, and improve physical function and quality of life.

Other options:

Option A- Osteoarthritis(OA) typically affects the weight-bearing joints like the knee, hip, and spine. It presents bilaterally with pain being the predominant symptom. The pain worsens with use. Other symptoms such as joint stiffness, swelling, giving away or locking can be present.

Option B- Gout has typical features of pain, swelling, and warmth of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The radiograph is normal in the initial stages while it shows erosions, punched-out lesions, and sclerosis with preservation of joint space in the late stages.

Option C- Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis.  Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is the most common joint involved in psoriatic arthritis. X-ray shows a characteristic pencil-in-cup appearance.

Related Pearl: Table of Arthritis and their susceptibility to Joints

 

Joint involved

Joints usually spared

Osteoarthritis

Cervical & Lumbosacral spine

Hip

Knee

1st metatarsophalangeal joint

PIP, DIP, 1st Carpometacarpal joint

Wrist

Elbow

Ankle

Metacarpophalangeal joint

Ankylosing Spondylitis

Sacroiliac joint

Intervertebral joints

 

Rheumatoid Arthritis

Proximal Interphalangeal joint

Metacarpophalangeal joint

Wrist

Feet

Knee

Shoulder

Distal Interphalangeal joint

questions.text: Dependent personality traits are related to which phase:
questions.solution:
The development of dependent personality traits is due to fixation in the oral stage of development, according to the psychosexual stages of development proposed by Sigmund Freud. He proposed five stages of development and stated that when the development of a child gets arrested at one stage, called fixation, it results in psychiatric disorders.

The phases are:

Phase of sexual development

Disorders resulting from fixation in this phase

Oral phase

(birth- 1.5 years)

Learning how to eat, mouth is the site of pleasure.

Alcohol dependence or drug dependence

Schizophrenia

Severe mood disorders

Dependent personality disorder

Anal phase

(1.5-3 years)

Toilet training, the site of pleasure is the anal region.

OCD

Phallic/Oedipal phase

(3-5 years)

Site of pleasure is the genital region.

Oedipus/Electra complex, which is the primary cause of hysteria.

Also, castration anxiety in boys and penis envy in girls.

Latency phase

(5-12 years)

Neurotic disorder

Genital phase

sexual orientation

(>12 years)

Neurotic disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent local anaesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
The most potent local anaesthetic among the following is bupivacaine.

Potency depends on hydrophobicity. Hydrophobicity can be increased by the addition of alkyl groups to the molecule.

Note: Dibucaine is the most potent, most toxic and longest acting local anaesthetic agent.

Related Pearl: Classification of Local Anesthetics based on the Potency

Low Potency

Procaine

Intermediate Potency

Mepivacaine

Prilocaine

Chloroprocaine

Lidocaine

High Potency

Tetracaine

Bupivacaine

Etidocaine

questions.text:
Consider the causes of alopecia. Which among the following cause(s) non-scarring alopecia?

1. Alopecia areata
2. Telogen effluvium
3. Androgenic alopecia
4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Non-scarring alopecia is caused by androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium.

Alopecia areata

It is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases, including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

Telogen effluvium 

It is a type of nonscarring alopecia that is marked by diffuse shedding of normal hair. This occurs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle.  It can be either acute or chronic.

Acute telogen effluvium occurs 2–3 months after a stressful event such as high fever, surgery, starvation, and hemorrhage. Hormonal fluctuations during the postpartum period can trigger it (telogen gravidarum). Telogen effluvium can result in a diffuse reduction in hair density but never total baldness. It generally resolves spontaneously.

Chronic telogen effluvium is used to describe the diffuse shedding of telogen hair for more than 6 months. Common causes include thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, and malnutrition. 

Androgenetic alopecia

It is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types: male-pattern and female-pattern hair loss. Male-pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scalp condition that affects post-menopausal women in particular and frequently involves the eyebrows. It is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood stained stools. The barium enema study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological image of the claw sign/pincer sign in barium enema is suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign -also known as the doughnut sign
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles the renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Other options:

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea and/or vomiting. It shows a coffee bean sign.

 

Option C: Barium enema radiograph in colonic diverticulitis shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

 

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes lead pipe appearance.

questions.text: Patient with a metallic foreign body in eye, which of the following investigation is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
MRI is contraindicated in:

  • Cardiac pacemakers (best response)
  • Aneurysmal metallic clips
  • Metallic foreign body
  • Cochlear implant
  • Claustrophobia (relative contraindication)
